series.short: "New Restrictions on Research and Development Tax Credits for Certain Companies"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This extract of the legislation restricts the ability of certain types of companies to claim Research and Development (R&D) expenditure credits.
* Simplified point 2: The extract adds a new section to the existing law, Section 104WA, which defines "ineligible companies" that cannot claim R&D expenditure credits. These include institutions of higher education, charities, and companies of a type specified by the Treasury through regulations.
* Simplified point 3: The amendments made by this section only apply to expenditure incurred on or after August 1st, 2015.

series.short: "Restrictions on Intangible Fixed Asset Deductions"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The section restricts the ability of companies to deduct expenses related to intangible fixed assets such as goodwill, customer relationships, and unregistered trademarks.
* Simplified point 2: Companies cannot deduct debits for these assets under Chapter 3 of the Taxes Act 2009, and any debits already deducted will be treated as non-trading debits.
* Simplified point 3: The restrictions only apply if the company acquired or created the relevant asset on or after July 8th, 2015.
* Simplified point 4: If a company acquired the asset before July 8th, 2015, or as part of an obligation under a contract that existed before that date, then the restrictions do not apply.
* Simplified point 5: The section also removes the requirement for a valuation of the intangible fixed assets for the purpose of Chapter 6.

series.short: "UK Companies Allowed to Choose Functional Currency for Financial Reporting"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The UK government is allowing certain companies to choose their own "functional currency" for financial reporting purposes.
* Simplified point 2: This change will affect how these companies calculate their profits and losses for tax purposes, and will allow them to use the currency that best reflects their main economic environment.
* Simplified point 3: The law specifically targets UK-resident investment companies and outlines the conditions under which they can make this election, as well as the procedures for doing so.
* Simplified point 4: The changes apply to periods of account beginning on or after January 1, 2016, but the law includes provisions for handling "straddling periods of account" that begin before January 1, 2016 and end on or after that date.

series.short: "Streamlining Group Relief Claims: A More Efficient Approach"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section of the legislation simplifies the claims for group relief in Consortium Conditions 2 and 3.
* Simplified point 2: It removes certain subsections and replaces words in other subsections to make the language more concise and easier to understand.
* Simplified point 3: The changes apply to accounting periods starting on or after December 10th, 2014.
* Simplified point 4: The amendments affect sections 129, 130, and 134 of the Corporation Tax Act 2010, as well as Schedule 6 to the Finance (No. 3) Act 2010.

series.short: The Finance (No. 2) Act 2015 Abolishes Relief Against Sum Charged for Controlled Foreign Companies
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Finance (No. 2) Act 2015 abolishes the relief against the sum charged for controlled foreign companies (CFCs).
* Simplified point 2: This means that CFCs will no longer receive relief against the sum charged for their accounting periods beginning on or after July 8, 2015.
* Simplified point 3: For CFCs with straddling periods (i.e., periods that fall both before and after July 8, 2015), the relief is apportioned on a just and reasonable basis between the two periods.
* Simplified point 4: The definition of "CFC," "accounting period" in relation to a CFC, and "chargeable company" remains the same as in Part 9A of TIOPA 2010.

series.short: "Legislative Change for Carried-Forward Losses in Controlled Foreign Companies"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This legislative change allows for the disallowance of deductions related to carried-forward losses if they were used to gain a tax advantage through the use of a controlled foreign company (CFC).
* Simplified point 2: The change applies to any company that has an accounting period that straddles July 8th, 2015, and treats the pre- and post-straddle periods separately for apportioning amounts brought into account for calculating taxable total profits.
* Simplified point 3: The change also defines "CFC charge advantage" as the avoidance or reduction of a charge or assessment under Part 9A of TIOPA 2010 (controlled foreign companies).
* Simplified point 4: The amendments made by this section have effect for the purposes of calculating the taxable total profits of companies for accounting periods beginning on or after July 8th, 2015.

series.short: "UK Tax Restitution Interest Definition and Rules"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This legislation defines "restitution interest" as profits related to claims for restitution against the UK's HMRC (Her Majesty's Revenue and Customs) for mistakes in taxation matters or unlawful collections of taxes.
* Simplified point 2: The definition of "restitution interest" includes interest paid or payable by HMRC, as well as amounts equivalent to interest, and covers situations where the interest is determined by a court or settled through an agreement.
* Simplified point 3: The legislation specifies that the definition of "restitution interest" does not include simple interest at a statutory rate, but allows for the inclusion of such interest in certain circumstances.
* Simplified point 4: The legislation provides that a court determination is considered "final" if it cannot be varied on appeal, and that any power to grant permission to appeal out of time is to be disregarded for the purposes of this section.

series.short: "Restitution Interest Definition and Conditions"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section defines when interest paid to a company can be considered "restitution interest" for the purposes of the Finance (No. 2) Act 2015.
* Simplified point 2: The section outlines two conditions that must be met for interest to qualify as restitution interest: (a) condition B must not have been met until after the interest was paid, and (b) the amount paid must be limited to simple interest at a statutory rate.
* Simplified point 3: If these conditions are not met, then the interest paid to the company is not considered restitution interest, but rather simple interest at a statutory rate.
* Simplified point 4: The section also specifies that the definition of "restitution interest" includes only the portion of the interest determined to be due, agreed upon, or otherwise paid that represents or is calculated by reference to simple interest at a statutory rate.
* Simplified point 5: The section further states that Section 357YC(7) applies in relation to this section, which provides additional guidance on how to calculate the amount of restitution interest owed.

series.short: "HMRC Restitution Interest Calculation Guidelines"
series.text:
* The extract sets out how "restitution interest" should be calculated and reported on for financial periods. Restitution interest is essentially interest paid on funds owed to HMRC due to tax avoidance schemes being found not to be effective.
* The extract specifies that the interest should be calculated using generally accepted accounting practices and should be included in the company's profit/loss calculations for the relevant period.
* If certain conditions are met, adjustments can be made to the interest payments after the end of the period they were originally due in, and time limits for making these adjustments do not apply.

series.short: "Financial Statement Comparability for Non-GAAP Compliant Companies"
series.text:
* The extract sets out rules for companies without GAAP-compliant accounts.
* If a company doesn't follow Generally Accepted Accounting Practice (GAAP) when preparing its financial statements, the extract provides a way to still apply certain rules as if they did follow GAAP.
* This ensures that the company's financial statements are comparable to those of other companies that do follow GAAP.
* The extract defines "GAAP-compliant accounts" as financial statements prepared according to widely accepted accounting principles.

series.short: "Restitution Interest Refunds: Navigating Appeal Outcomes and Multiple Determinations"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section deals with situations where a company is owed restitution interest (i.e., interest on money owed to them), but an appeal against the original decision is made after the deadline.
* Simplified point 2: If the appeal is successful and the original decision is overturned, then the restitution interest owed to the company is effectively erased, and any taxes already paid on that interest are refunded.
* Simplified point 3: The section also covers cases where multiple appeals are made, and the final determination is different each time, resulting in multiple refunds of taxes paid on the restitution interest.
* Simplified point 4: The section provides for adjustments to be made to ensure that the company receives the correct amount of restitution interest and taxes are refunded accordingly.

series.short: "Tax Countermeasures Against Avoidance Schemes: Adjusting Owed Amounts"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section counters the tax benefits of avoidance schemes by making adjustments to the amounts owed.
* Simplified point 2: Adjustments can be made through an assessment, modification of an assessment, amendment, or other means.
* Simplified point 3: The section defines "relevant avoidance arrangements" and "restitution-related tax advantage" in section 357YI.

series.short: "Tax Advantage Definitions Under Section 357YH of the Finance (No. 2) Act 2015"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section defines the meaning of "arrangements" and "tax advantage" for the purposes of Section 357YH of the Finance (No. 2) Act 2015.
* Simplified point 2: The section explains that certain agreements or schemes may be considered "relevant avoidance arrangements" if their primary purpose is to secure a tax advantage for the company, but only if the arrangement is not consistent with wholly commercial arrangements.
* Simplified point 3: The section also outlines the types of tax advantages that are covered under the definition of "tax advantage", including repayments of tax, reduced charges to tax, deferred payments of tax, and advanced repayments of tax.
* Simplified point 4: The section further clarifies that the definitions of "arrangements" and "tax advantage" apply not just to Section 357YH, but also to any other provision of the Act that refers to these terms.

series.short: "Tax Law Examples of Irrelevant Avoidance Arrangements"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The extract describes examples of how arrangements might not be considered "relevant avoidance arrangements" for the purposes of tax law, even if they were made to obtain a restitution-related tax advantage.
* Simplified point 2: These examples include eliminating or reducing restitution interest charges, preventing or delaying the recognition of profits, and ensuring that receipts are treated differently for accounting purposes.
* Simplified point 3: The extract highlights that these examples do not necessarily mean that the arrangements are not subject to tax, but rather that they may not fall under the specific category of "relevant avoidance arrangements" for the purposes of section 357YH of the Finance (No. 2) Act 2015.

series.short: "Restitution Interest Exclusion in Corporation Tax Calculations"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This clause excludes restitution interest from the total profits calculation for corporation tax purposes.
* Simplified point 2: The clause prohibits the use of reliefs and set-offs against corporation tax liabilities at the restitution payments rate.
* Simplified point 3: The clause specifically excludes certain reliefs and set-offs, including those listed in paragraph 8(1) of Schedule 18 to the Finance Act 1998.
* Simplified point 4: The clause prohibits the setting off of income tax, corporation tax, or other amounts against corporation tax liabilities at the restitution payments rate.

series.short: "Tax Avoidance Measures for Restitution Claims"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section of the legislation deals with the assignment of rights related to claims for restitution, specifically focusing on situations where the transfer of these rights is done to avoid paying corporation tax.
* Simplified point 2: The section outlines conditions under which such assignments are considered valid, including that the primary purpose of the transfer must be to secure a tax advantage, and that the resulting restitution interest must be treated as arising to the transferor for corporation tax purposes.
* Simplified point 3: The definition of "tax advantage" is provided in section 357YI, and includes any reduction or avoidance of liability to tax, or an increase in a refund of tax.
* Simplified point 4: The section only applies to transfers made on or after October 21st, 2015, and only to companies that are within the charge to corporation tax under this part of the legislation.

series.short: "Tax Avoidance Prevention for Non-UK Resident Companies with Restitution Interests"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section deals with the case of a non-UK resident company that has a "restitution interest" (not defined here) and whose residence was changed to avoid taxes. The company will be considered a UK resident for the purposes of applying this part of the law if the rights that gave rise to the restitution interest were earned before the company left the UK.
* Simplified point 2: The company will be treated as if it did not dispose of its assets when it left the UK, and any necessary adjustments will be made. Time limits for making these adjustments will be ignored.
* Simplified point 3: The purpose of this section is to prevent companies from moving abroad solely to avoid paying taxes on their restitution interests. By treating the company as if it remained a UK resident for the purposes of this part of the law, the government can ensure that the company pays the appropriate amount of tax on those interests.

series.short: UK Government's Duty to Deduct Corporate Tax on Restitution Payments
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The UK government has a duty to deduct corporation tax from payments made to companies as restitution interest.
* Simplified point 2: This duty arises when the UK government makes payments of interest to companies due to mistakes in taxation matters, such as overpayments or unlawful collections.
* Simplified point 3: The restitution payments rate will be applied to the gross payment before deducting the sum representing corporation tax.
* Simplified point 4: The definition of "interest" includes amounts equivalent to interest, and the term "equivalent to interest" refers to amounts determined by the time value of money.

series.short: "Tax Deductions and Repayments: Treatment of Amounts Deducted Under Section 357YO of the Finance (No. 2) Act 2015"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section of the legislation deals with the treatment of amounts deducted under section 357YO of the Finance (No. 2) Act 2015.
* Simplified point 2: The section states that an amount deducted from an interest payment in accordance with section 357YO(2) is treated for all purposes as paid by the company on account of its liability to corporation tax, as restitution interest, under this Part.
* Simplified point 3: If the Commissioners have made a deduction under section 357YO(2) from the gross payment and the company becomes liable to repay the net amount to the Commissioners, the Commissioners must repay the amount treated as paid by the company and make any necessary adjustments.
* Simplified point 4: If the condition in subsection (2)(b) is met by virtue of a company becoming liable to repay to the Commissioners the amount paid as mentioned in subsection (2)(a), then this Part has effect as if the company were liable to repay the gross payment to the Commissioners.
* Simplified point 5: Subsections (3) and (4) have effect with the appropriate modifications if the condition in subsection (2)(b) is met in relation to part but not the whole of the gross amount mentioned in subsection (2)(a).

series.short: "Corporation Tax Assessment by HMRC Officers"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The section allows HMRC officers to make an assessment of the amount of corporation tax that a company is liable to pay for a specific period, based on their opinion of the amount of restitution income arising to the company during that period.
* Simplified point 2: The assessment can include not only the amount of restitution income but also any other matters relevant to the calculation of the corporation tax liability for that period.
* Simplified point 3: The assessment must be served on the company with a statement of the date on which it is issued, and the company must pay the assessed amount within 30 days of receiving the notice.

series.short: "Tax Interest Payments: Understanding Your Rights and Obligations"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Finance (No. 2) Act 2015 states that if the Inland Revenue deducts too much tax from interest earned, they will pay interest on the excess amount from the "material date" (the date tax was deducted) until the date the excess is repaid.
* Simplified point 2: The interest paid will be calculated at the rate specified in Section 178 of the Finance Act 1989.

series.short: "Disputing Deductions from Corporation Tax Payments: Appeal Mechanism"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The clause allows for appeals to be made against deductions made by HMRC from payments of corporation tax.
* Simplified point 2: The appeal must be made in writing within 30 days of receiving the notice under section 357YO(2).
* Simplified point 3: The clause provides a mechanism for disputing deductions made by HMRC from payments of corporation tax.

series.short: "Corporate Tax Exemptions for Restitution Payments"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This clause exempts companies from paying corporation tax on certain amounts that they have paid out as restitution, such as compensation for wrongdoing or damages.
* Simplified point 2: The exemption applies only if the company has paid the restitution amounts at the "restitution payments rate", which is a lower rate of tax than the standard corporation tax rate.
* Simplified point 3: The clause ensures that these restitution payments are not included in the calculation of the company's total corporation tax liability for the accounting period.

series.short: "Tax Regulation Changes: Retroactive Effect Allowed with Parliament Approval"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This legislation allows the Treasury to create regulations that can modify the payment of corporation tax on restitution interest.
* Simplified point 2: These regulations cannot remove or limit the right to appeal, increase the tax rate, or apply to claims that have already been settled before October 21st, 2015.
* Simplified point 3: The regulations can have retroactive effect but only if they are approved by the House of Commons.
* Simplified point 4: The regulations can include provisions for incidental, supplementary, or transitional arrangements.
* Simplified point 5: The legislation also makes changes to other laws related to company tax returns, assessments, and penalties for late payments.

series.short: "Corporate Tax Regulations Effectiveness Clarification"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Corporate Tax Instalment Payments Regulations 2014 will be considered to have been effective since its beginning instead of its end.
* Simplified point 2: This means that sections 279F and 279G of the Capital Gains Tax (CGT) Act 2010 will apply to accounting periods starting before and ending on or after April 1, 2015, and paragraph 22 of Schedule 1 to the Finance Act 2014 should be ignored accordingly.

series.short: "New Transfer Pricing Rules for Trading Stock Disposals"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The changes in trading stock not made in the course of trade will now be subject to transfer pricing rules.
* Simplified point 2: If the market value of the stock is greater than the Part 4 TIOPA amount, then an additional amount must be brought into account in calculating the profits of the trade.
* Simplified point 3: The amendments made by this section apply in relation to a disposal or acquisition made on or after 8 July 2015, unless it is made pursuant to an obligation that was unconditional before that date.
* Simplified point 4: The amendments also apply to the valuation of trading stock on cessation, where the market value of the stock is greater than the Part 4 TIOPA amount.

series.short: "Investment Partnerships Tax Law: Carried Interest Rules & Deductions"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This law states that when someone (called "A") makes an investment through a partnership, they might receive a share of the profits called "carried interest". If A sells their stake in the partnership, they will have to pay taxes on the carried interest as if it were income.
* Simplified point 2: The law only applies if the carried interest was earned because of A's involvement in the partnership, and not if it was earned through other means, like a salary or other types of income.
* Simplified point 3: The law allows for some deductions to be made from the carried interest before taxes are calculated, but only certain deductions are allowed.
* Simplified point 4: If A acquired the right to the carried interest from someone else for a price, then the amount of taxes owed can be reduced by the amount paid.
* Simplified point 5: The law defines some key terms used in the section, including "co-investment", "co-investment repayment or return", and "trade".

series.short: "Carried Interest Taxation: Earning Income Upfront"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This clause states that when an individual sells, varies, loses, or cancels a right to carried interest, any consideration they receive or are owed will be considered carried interest at the time of the transaction.
* Simplified point 2: However, this rule does not apply if the consideration is a disguised fee for the purpose of section 809EZA of the Income Tax Act 2007.
* Simplified point 3: The purpose of this clause is to ensure that individuals pay tax on their carried interest income at the time it is earned, rather than delaying payment until a later date.

series.short: "Carried Interest Taxation for Non-UK Services"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The clause states that carried interest gained by individuals performing services outside the UK will be considered foreign chargeable gains subject to tax.
* Simplified point 2: This means that individuals who earn carried interest through investments made outside the UK will have their gains subject to UK tax only to the extent they performed services outside the UK.
* Simplified point 3: The clause aims to prevent individuals from avoiding UK tax on their carried interest gains by shifting their services to non-UK locations.

series.short: "Carried Interest Tax Relief Restrictions: Preventing Abuse for Personal Gain."
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The clause prevents carried interest tax relief for individuals if the main purpose of certain arrangements is to avoid the application of the relief.
* Simplified point 2: The clause targets anti-avoidance measures to ensure that carried interest tax relief is only granted when it is intended to be used for its original purpose, rather than being manipulated to avoid tax liabilities.

series.short: "Tax Law Provisions for Carried Interests and Double Taxation"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This law prevents individuals from being doubly taxed on their carried interests.
* Simplified point 2: It allows for consequential adjustments to be made to avoid double taxation, and these adjustments can be made despite any time limits imposed by law.
* Simplified point 3: The value of any consequential adjustments made cannot exceed the lesser of the capital gains tax charged and the tax charged on the individual or other persons.
* Simplified point 4: Individuals can make claims for consequential adjustments, and officers of Revenue and Customs must make such adjustments as are just and reasonable.

series.short: "Relief for External Investors on Disposal of Partnership Assets in Investment Schemes"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The clause provides relief for external investors on the disposal of partnership assets in an investment scheme, reducing the amount of chargeable gain by the amount invested in the fund that is referable to the asset disposed of.
* Simplified point 2: The relief is subject to certain conditions, including that the external investor must make a claim for relief and that the amount deducted under section 38(1)(a) in respect of consideration given for the acquisition of the asset must be taken into account.

series.short: Carried Interest Deferral Rules: Understanding the Basics
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section defines "arise" for the purposes of Chapter 5 of the Finance (No. 2) Act 2015. It states that carried interest "arises" to an individual if it meets certain conditions related to deferral of the payment of the carried interest.
* Simplified point 2: The section outlines various conditions that must be met for the carried interest to be considered deferred, including that the provision of the sum to the individual must be deferred (whether pending the meeting of any conditions or otherwise), and that the individual must have a share (determined on a just and reasonable basis) of any carried interest that has been deferred.
* Simplified point 3: The section also includes provisions related to the treatment of deferred carried interest in certain circumstances, such as when the individual is connected with a company that is liable to pay corporation tax, or when the deferral is the effect of genuine commercial arrangements.
* Simplified point 4: The section provides that the enjoyment conditions (which relate to the use or disposal of the carried interest) must be met in order for the carried interest to be considered deferred, and that the condition in subsection (6)(b), (c) or (d) is to be treated as not met if it would be met only by reason of the individual holding shares or an interest in shares in a company.

series.short: Chapter 5 Amendments: Definitions and Effective Dates
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section defines key terms used in Chapter 5 of the Finance (No. 2) Act 2015, such as "arrangements," "carried interest," and "investment scheme." These terms are taken from existing tax laws and have specific meanings within the context of the chapter.

Carried interest arising on or after July 8, 2015, is subject to the new rules, except for variations occurring before October 22, 2015.
* Simplified point 3: The section also specifies that the amendments do not apply to disposals of assets or partnerships before the effective dates.

* Simplified point 5: The section states that the amendments made by the act only apply to carried interest arising under certain arrangements, and do not affect the general rule that carried interest is subject to income tax as employment income.

series.short: "Tax Changes on Disguised Investment Management Fees"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This legislative change clarifies that disguised investment management fees will be subject to tax if they are not reasonably comparable to the returns received by external investors.
* Simplified point 2: The change expands the definition of "management fee" to include any other factors relevant to determining the size of the return on the investment, making it easier to identify and tax such fees.
* Simplified point 3: The amendments apply to sums arising on or after July 8th, 2015, when the arrangements under which the sums arose were made.
* Simplified point 4: The term "arise" has the same meaning as it does for the purposes of Chapter 5E of Part 13 of ITA 2007, which relates to the taxation of income from investments.

series.short: "New Rules for Carried Interest and Disguised Investment Management Fees"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The text describes how carried interest and disguised investment management fees can arise to individuals, including the conditions under which they do so.
* Simplified point 2: The text introduces new rules for when these fees arise to individuals, including the requirement that the fees must be calculated at some point to benefit the individual, and that the individual must have some degree of control over the funds.

* Simplified point 4: The text includes provisions for when the fees arise to connected parties, such as family members or business partners, and how they should be taxed.

series.short: "UK Government Modifies Vehicle Excise Duty and Insurance Premium Tax Laws to Promote Environmental Sustainability"
series.text:
* The UK government enacted the Finance (No. 2) Act 2015 to modify the Vehicle Excise Duty (VID) and Insurance Premium Tax (IPT) laws.
* The new law establishes a graduated system of vehicle excise duty based on carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions, with lower rates for cars with lower emissions.
* The law also modifies IPT by increasing the standard rate from 6% to 9.5%.
* The changes aim to reduce environmental impact while maintaining revenue stability.
* The law's provisions include a transition period for existing agreements and grandfathering provisions for certain vehicles.
* The modified IPT rate will take effect on November 1st, 2015, while the VED changes will go into effect on April 1st, 2017.
* The law also includes minor adjustments to the aggregates levy and climate change levy.

series.short: "UK Tax Legislation: Client Notification Obligations & Debt Enforcement"
series.text:

* Simplified point 5: The legislation allows for the alteration of the special repayment rate through regulations, and provides for the rounding up or down of rates, and for circumstances in which the alteration of a rate of interest is or is not to take place.

series.short: "Finance (No. 2) Act 2015 Abbreviations and Short Title"
